awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Multi-stimuli Responsive DNA-Nanoshells - Compartmentalizing Molecules at the Nanoscale for Enhanced Reaction Selectivity and Sensitivity
awd_abstract_narration:
Viruses have evolved self-destruct mechanisms that allow them to release their contents when they are inside the right host. The viruses are decorated with molecules that trigger their degradation when they encounter specific enzymes found within certain biological systems. Using inspiration from how virus particles respond to their environment in highly specific ways, the research group of Professor Jessica Rouge at the University of Connecticut is developing new chemical strategies to synthesize shells of very small size that can both controllably encapsulate small molecules and release them in response to specific stimuli in complex mixtures. Such strategies are important for developing more sensitive biological sensors and more accurate drug delivery systems.  This project provides graduate and undergraduate students multidisciplinary research training in nanoscience, chemical synthesis, and biochemistry.  In addition, an initiative entitled "Catalyzing Curie-osity" is launched to engage high school teachers and students throughout the state of Connecticut.  Through this joint initiative with the UConn Early College Experience program, affordable lab protocols are being designed focusing on the fundamental tools and techniques of bio-nanoscience. These lab modules will be individually tailored to the needs and resources of specific high schools, giving students hands -n experience with this exciting class of nanomaterials and preparing them for future careers related to nanotechnology and chemistry. 

With the support of the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry program, the Rouge Group is developing novel chemical crosslinking strategies that can be incorporated into DNA nanomaterials for controlling their assembly and disassembly in complex biological environments. Using a novel DNA-surfactant assembly strategy that generates DNA nanoshells compatible with cells and enzymes, the major goal of this work is to synthesize a combination of peptide and synthetic crosslinkages that can maintain the nanomaterials stability in biological systems while exhibiting selectivity for certain chemical and biochemical stimuli. These stimuli, including temperature and pH changes, or exposure to specific enzyme classes, will be used to gate the release of small molecules for initiating chemical and/or biochemical reactions. Through this work the following goals are addressed: 1) the design of a library of thermoresponsive crosslinkers that enables remotely controlled substrate release, 2) the design of ligand-cargo communication schemes for sensing the local environment of the DNA-nanoshells, and 3) control over solution reaction selectivity via stepwise substrate release from multi-layered peptide crosslinked DNA-nanoshells. Compartmentalization of different substrates within the DNA-nanoshell layers will allow the team to study release rates and subsequent reaction rates of diverse molecules in aqueous systems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Over the course of this award we have achieved the synthesis of several new DNA nanoshell designs that can enable both communication of the nanoshell with its environment and the controlled release of molecules from its interior. Inspired by the design of viruses, we were able to chemically construct configurations in which we could make multi-layered particles, wherein each layer opens in response to a different trigger (Figure 1), while at the same time expanding the types of stimuli that could trigger the particles programmed degradation. These triggers included responses to reducing environments, enzymes and temperature changes.

Through the design of reversible chemistries (Figure 2) that are stable at room temperature but require elevated temperatures to break down, we were able to build a DNA nanoshell that could degrade in response to heating. These particles are the first step towards designing materials that can be broken down when localized heat is applied to a nanoparticle. We aim in the future to incorporate iron oxide nanoparticles within our nanoshells so that if a magnetic field is applied it could create localized heating and breakdown the nanoshell it would release cargo into cells without heating the entire cell. This would be a step towards achieving remote gene silencing if the cargo released is capable of suppressing gene expression.

We also developed a novel dye labeled surfactant that could tell us if our nanoshell is still in tact or not, which is useful for determining and confirming which environments trigger the degradation of our DNA nanoshells.

In addition to expanding the chemistry of the breakdown mechanism of our nanoshells, we investigated ways in which to convert the interior of our nanoshell design such that it could encapsule a greater breath of cargo than before (Figure 3). Instead of being limited to small molecule dyes and drugs in the hydrophobic core of our nanoshells, we discovered that templating the nanoshells around metal organic frameworks (MOFs) could enable us the ability to incorporate larger hydrophilic cargo such as proteins, plasmids and even mRNA. With this discovery we were able to show that we could gate the conversion of an enzymes substrate to product formation using pH as a control as MOFs are broken down under acidic conditions. We also found that by making a multi-layered nanoshells with both inorganic and organic components that we could make a dual-gated system to triggered degradation, significantly increasing the controllable degradation of these materials. We showed that we could program an enzyme to break down the DNA nanoshell outer layer and that a drop in pH could then be used to degrade the MOF layer, preventing unwanted premature release of cargo from the system.

From there we showed that by incorporating nucleic acids in the interior of these MOF nanoshells that we could control the expression of proteins when we encapsulated plasmids or mRNA (Figure 4). To our knowledge this is one of the first examples of an enzyme gated expression of mRNA. Lastly, we discovered that by developing chemical strategies that interface the micelle core of our DNA nanoshells with MOFs we could stabilize biomolecules, including stabilizing mRNA at ambient temperatures. This has important implications for the growing world of mRNA therapeutics and vaccines as it is critical to maintain the stability of mRNA when stored or transported for clinical use.

From an educational point of view, we developed several outreach initiatives in which we brought high school students from the state of Connecticut to our lab to participate in science experiments related to DNA nanomaterials. We trained several high school students from local area schools in the areas of chemistry, biochemistry and materials science. A major product of this funding was the development of a virtual version of our laboratory, designed such that a high school class/student and their teacher can virtually walk through our lab, clicking on the equipment in our spaces and being able to learn about what each piece of equipment does either by reading about it or by watching a YouTube video featuring a member of our lab describing how it works and how we use it in our research (Figure 5). We hope that this new platform will allow students and teachers the ability to learn about nanoscience and research tools even if they do not have the means to physically visit our lab, broadening the participation of students in STEM related activities and inspiring them to seek future research experiences if possible.

 


Last Modified: 09/25/2024
Modified by: Jessica Rouge
